column4: I need to sudo chroot [folder] , but when I try it says that /bin/bash is not found.  Anybody know why?
after you chroot'd that'swhere the new root is, and /usr probably isn't in it.
basiclly you've cut yourself off from the rest of the system
Well, it has bash in folder/bin.  Hmm....
what is your $PATH and what did you chroot to?
you changed root to /home/asc/folder  right?  is there a bin/bash in folder
I'd think that having /bin in the path before chrooting would make the folder/bin programs work.
a bunch of Qs does folder/lib exist - with a full compliment of libraries.  Is bash a link? is it a statuc copy?
I don't have Ubuntu running right now so I can't see what my os looks like.  in you can't find bash, then something is missing (you already know that.)
yes, there are libraries in folder/lib.  Bash is a static copy.
the commands 'cd' then ls show bin and lib, and more - looks like the system root (sort of)
yes.  The contents of /home/asc/folder seem to be identical to a clean ubuntu install
uh, hmm.  If folder/bin/bash was owned by asc instead of by root, would that cause a problem?
could be, or the rest of the permissions were wrong, same with bin/  it should be executable
It won't let me change the permissions on anything.  Maybe trying this on a FAT filesystem isn't a good idea
yup, working on FAT system is tricky at best - there are no real 'permissions'  think DOS
nix_ferret after chrooting - the old root does not exist! and ther is no way back
